metadata.title: [Talk] Vac, Waku v2 and Ethereum Messaging

metadata.summary: Talk from Taipei Ethereum Meetup. Read on to find out about our journey from Whisper to Waku v2, as well as how Waku v2 can be useful for Etherum Messaging.

metadata.title: Privacy-preserving p2p economic spam protection in Waku v2
metadata.name: Privacy-preserving p2p economic spam protection in Waku v2
metadata.author: sanaztaheri
metadata.summary: This post is going to give you an overview of how spam protection can be achieved in Waku Relay through rate-limiting nullifiers. We will cover a summary of spam-protection methods in centralized and p2p systems, and the solution overview and details of the economic spam-protection method. The open issues and future steps are discussed in the end.

metadata.title: Presenting JS-Waku: Waku v2 in the Browser

metadata.author: franck
metadata.summary: JS-Waku is bringing Waku v2 to the browser. Learn what we achieved so far and what is next in our pipeline!

metadata.title: [Talk at COSCUP] Vac, Waku v2 and Ethereum Messaging
metadata.name: [Talk at COSCUP] Vac, Waku v2 and Ethereum Messaging
metadata.author: oskarth
metadata.summary: Learn more about Waku v2, its origins, goals, protocols, implementation and ongoing research. Understand how it is used and how it can be useful for messaging in Ethereum.

metadata.name: Waku v1 vs Waku v2: Bandwidth Comparison

metadata.summary: A local comparison of bandwidth profiles showing significantly improved scalability in Waku v2 over Waku v1.

metadata.author: s1fr0
metadata.summary: We provide an overview of the Noise Protocol Framework as a tool to design efficient and secure key-exchange mechanisms in Waku2.

metadata.title: Waku Privacy and Anonymity Analysis Part I: Definitions and Waku Relay
metadata.name: Waku Privacy and Anonymity Analysis Part I: Definitions and Waku Relay
metadata.author: kaiserd

metadata.title: Building Privacy-Protecting Infrastructure
metadata.name: Building Privacy-Protecting Infrastructure
metadata.author: oskarth
metadata.summary: What is privacy-protecting infrastructure? Why do we need it and how we can build it? We'll look at Waku, the communication layer for Web3. We'll see how it uses ZKPs to incentivize and protect the Waku network. We'll also look at Zerokit, a library that makes it easier to use ZKPs in different environments. After reading this, I hope you'll better understand the importance of privacy-protecting infrastructure and how we can build it.

metadata.title: Waku for All Decentralized Applications and Infrastructures
metadata.name: Waku for All Decentralized Applications and Infrastructures
metadata.author: franck
metadata.categories: waku, dapp, infrastructure, public good, platform, operator
metadata.summary:
Waku is an open communication protocol and network. Decentralized apps and infrastructure can use Waku for their
communication needs. It is designed to enable dApps and decentralized infrastructure projects to have secure, private,
scalable communication. Waku is available in several languages and platforms, from Web to mobile to desktop to cloud. 
Initially, We pushed Waku adoption to the Web ecosystem, we learned that Waku is usable in a variety of complex applications
and infrastructure projects. We have prioritized our effort to make Waku usable on various platforms and environments.
